bestBHT.bht: Jesus was first taken before Annas, the de jure high priest, before being brought to Caiaphas, the de facto high priest, for a formal meeting of the Sanhedrin. This transfer from Annas to Caiaphas is not explicitly mentioned in the narrative, but the natural impression is that the scene around the fire took place overnight. Mark also mentions the three orders of the Sanhedrin, highlighting the significance of this meeting. The whole Sanhedrin, including the high priest, took part in this trial of Jesus. (Based on Mark 14:53 and related passages)

Henry Alford: Caiaphas, de facto, and in the view of our narrator.
Jesus was first taken before Annas, who was de jure the high priest.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: It was then a full and formal meeting of the Sanhedrim.
The natural impression is that the scene around the fire took place overnight.
If our Lord had to be transferred from the residence of Annas to that of Caiaphas, one is apt to wonder that there is no mention of His being marched from the one to the other.
Philip Schaff: Mark 14:53. With him, i.e., the high-priest. Mark mentions the three orders of the Sanhedrin.
John Gill: And they led Jesus away to the high priest....
This was done, after they had took Jesus and bound him...
Even the whole sanhedrim, who met at Caiaphas's house...

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus was first taken before Annas, the de jure high priest, before being brought to Caiaphas, the de facto high priest, for a formal meeting of the Sanhedrin. This transfer from Annas to Caiaphas is not explicitly mentioned in the narrative, but the natural impression is that the scene around the fire took place overnight. Mark also mentions the three orders of the Sanhedrin, highlighting the significance of this meeting. The whole Sanhedrin, including the high priest, took part in this trial of Jesus. Jesus was taken before Annas, who was the de jure high priest, and then brought to Caiaphas, the de facto high priest, for a formal meeting of the Sanhedrim. The transfer from Annas to Caiaphas is not explicitly mentioned, but the impression is that the scene around the fire occurred overnight. Mark also mentions the three orders of the Sanhedrim, emphasizing the importance of this trial. The entire Sanhedrim, along with the high priest, participated in the trial of Jesus.

Jesus was first taken before Annas, the de jure high priest, and later brought to Caiaphas, the de facto high priest, for a formal gathering of the Sanhedrin. While the transfer from Annas to Caiaphas is not explicitly mentioned, the implication is that the events took place overnight. Mark highlights the significance of this trial by mentioning the three orders of the Sanhedrin. It is notable that the entire Sanhedrin, including the high priest, played a role in the proceedings.

Jesus first appeared before Annas, who was the de jure high priest, before being brought to Caiaphas, the de facto high priest, for a formal meeting of the Sanhedrim. Though the transfer between Annas and Caiaphas is not explicitly mentioned, it seems that the events around the fire took place overnight. The significance of this trial is underscored by Mark's mention of the three orders of the Sanhedrin. Notably, the entire Sanhedrin, along with the high priest, were involved in the trial proceedings.

Jesus first appeared before Annas, the de jure high priest, before being taken to Caiaphas, the de facto high priest, for a formal meeting of the Sanhedrin. The transfer between Annas to Caiaphas is not mentioned, but it is implied that the scene around the fire occurred overnight. Mark's mention of the three orders of the Sanhedrin highlights the significance of this trial, where the entire Sanhedrin, including the high priest, played a role in the proceedings.
